column5:
1 1/2 oz gin
3/4 oz Lillet Blanc
3/4 oz freshly squeezed orange juice
2 dashes Bitters #9
column6: Combine all the ingredients except the garnish in a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake until chilled and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass. Garnish with the cherry.

column1: And to All a Good Night ____
column5:
1 1/2 oz. bourbon
3/4 oz. reposado tequila
3/4 oz. Cherry Heering
2 dashes Regans' orange bitters
1 dash Bitters #9
Ice cubes
column6: Combine ingredients in a mixing glass with ice and stir until cold. Strain into a glass and garnish. Makes 2 servings.

Presidio Social Club

column5:
1 1/2 oz añejo rum
1/2 oz orange curacao
1/4 oz fresh squeezed lime juice
2 dashes Bitters #9
Ginger beer
Orange wheel
column6: Build the rum, curacao, lime juice, and bitters in a highball glass filled with ice. Top with ginger beer and stir. Garnish with lime and orange wheels.

1 slice Habanero muddled
column6: Stir together ingredients in rocks glass, crushed ice. Garnish lime twist.

column5:

¼ oz Campari
1 oz gin
2 dashes Bitters #9
column6: Combine ingredients. Top with prosecco, serve in champagne flute. Garnish with strawberry slice

column5:
1 750 ml bottle Banks 5 Island Rum
18 ounces Sencha Green Tea
1 375ml bottle Noilly Prat Dry Vermouth
6 ounces St. Germain Liqueur
½ ounce Bitters #9
column6:
Combine all ingredients and chill in a refrigerator.
Serve in a bowl with a large block of ice.
Garnish each serving with grated nutmeg.

chilled champagne
column6: Place the sugar cube on the bottom of a champagne flute or coupe glass. Douse the sugar cube with bitters and fill the glass with champagne. Garnish with the lemon twist.

column5:
2 oz rye or bourbon
1/4 oz simple syrup
3 dashes Bitters #9
column6: Combine the rye or bourbon, simple syrup, and bitters in a mixing glass filled with ice. Stir until chilled and strain into a chilled double-rocks glass filled with large pieces of cracked ice or a large ice cube. Garnish with the lemon or orange zest.

column5:
Splash of absinthe, Herbsaint, or Pernod
2 oz rye
1/4 oz simple syrup
2 generous dashes Peychaud's bitters
2 generous dashes Bitters #9
column6: Add the absinthe to a chilled old-fashioned glass. Roll the glass around to coat the interior of the glass and shake out any excess liquid. Combine the rye, simple syrup, and bitters in a mixing glass filled with ice. Stir until chilled and strain into the prepared glass. Rub the lemon zest around the glass and serve with the zest resting on the rim.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column5:
1 1/2 oz. cognac
3/4 oz. Campari
1/4 oz. maraschino liqueur
1 dash Bitters #9
column6: Add ingredients to mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir well for 30 seconds and strain into a chilled glass. Garnish.

column1: Cuba Libre with Bitters Ice Cubes ____
column5:
Several dashes Bitters #9
1 lime
2 oz light rum
Mexican Coca-Cola
column6: Cut the lime in half and squeeze the lime juice into a highball glass. Drop one of the spent lime halves into the bottom of the glass. Fill the glass with the Bitters #9 ice and pour in the rum. Top off with Coca-Cola. Stir and serve.
column7: For the bitters ice cubes: Fill an ice cube tray with water, add 1 or 2 dashes of Bitters #9 to each section and freeze. Use as soon as possible.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column5:
1 oz ginger-lime syrup
2 oz Gosling's Black Seal rum
2 dashes Bitters #9
2 dashes Scrappy's lime bitters 
Ginger beer
column6: Combine the ginger-lime syrup rum, and both bitters in a highball glass filled with ice. Top off with the ginger beer. Squeeze the wedge of limeinto the drink, dropping the spent lime into the glass.Stir and serve.
column7: For the ginger-lime syrup: In a medium saucepan, combine 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, two 3-inch knobs of ginger (sliced into coins), and the zest of two limes. Bring to a simmer, stirring occasionally to dissolve the sugar. At the first crack of a boil, remove from the heat. Once it has cooled, pour the syrup through a strainer and store in a glass jar. The syrup will keep in the refrigerator up to a month.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column5:
3/4 oz Clear Creek Pear Brandy
3/4 oz St. Germain
2 dashes Bitters #9
column6: Shake (I know the rules but it is better for this drink) 6 seconds double strain in a cocktail glass top with a dry pear cider garnish with nutmeg
column8: Jermane Whitehead

column5:
2 oz Ron Zacapa Solera 23 Rum
1/2 barspoon Sugar Cane Syrup
1 dash Angostura Bitters
1 dash Bittermens Xocolatl Mole Bitters
3 dashes Bitters #9
Absinthe Rinse (or Herbsaint or Ricard)
column6: Fill a double old fashioned glass with ice and a small amount of Absinthe. Stir the Rum, Sugar Cane Syrup and bitters in an ice filled shaker glass. Dump the ice from the old fashioned glass and rotate the glass to ensure that the rinse coats the entire inside of the glass. Strain into the glass.
column8:
Joaquín Simó
Death & Co.
New York City

column5:
2 sprigs fresh mint
1/2 oz simple syrup
2 oz Bitters #9
2 1/2 oz bourbon
column6: Place the 2 sprigs of fresh mint in the palm of one hand and give them a smack with your other hand to wake them up. Then strip the leaves from their stems and add the mint leaves, simple syrup and bitters to a julep cup or highball glass and gently muddle. Add the bourbon and fill the cup two-thirds of the way with crushed ice. Stir vigorously until a layer of condensation coats the julep cup. Then add more crushed ice to the cup, so that the ice rises over the top. Garnish with the 2 or 3 sprigs of fresh mint and serve with a short straw.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column5:
1 oz gin
1 oz Campari
1 oz sweet vermouth
1 dash orange bitters
1 dash Bitters #9
column6:
Build all the ingredients except the garnish in an old fashioned glass filled with ice. Stir. 

To garnish, use a paring knife to cut a good-sized oval of zest from an orange. Hold the zest over the glass between your thumb and index finger. With your other ahnd, light a match and then place it between the orange zest and the glass. Slowly press the edges of the zest together, folding it in half, to release the citrus oils, which will ignite in little sparks over the drink.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column5:
1½ oz. Old Forester Whiskey
¾ oz. lemon juice
¾ oz. simple syrup
2 dashes Bitters #9
column6:
Pour the whiskey, lemon juice, bitters, and sugar syrup into a cocktail shaker with ice cubes.
Shake well. 
Garnish with the cherry.
column8: Volstead, Austin

column5:
1 Egg White
½ oz. Lime Juice
1 oz. Calvados or Applejack
1 oz. Pear Creek Brandy
1 ½ oz. St. Germaine
2 dashes of Scrappy's Cardamom Bitters
1 dash Bitters #9
column6: Shake vigorously and strain through tea strainer into cocktail glass or snifter. Garnish with a orange zest.
column8:
Andre Ellis McDade
Oliver's

column5:
2 oz pisco
1 oz freshly squeezed lime or lemon juice
1/2 oz simple syrup
1 small egg white
column6: Combine all the ingredients except the garnish in a cocktail shaker and dry shake (without ice) for at least 10 seconds to fully incorporate the egg white. Add ice and continue shaking until chilled and strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass. Dot the top of the drink with 4 drops of bitters (this is where an eyedropper to dispense your bitters comes in handy). Delicately run a toothpick or stirrer through the bitters to create a swirling pattern.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column5:
1/2 oz blood orange syrup
1 oz Aperol
1 oz Lillet Blanc
1 dash orange bitters
1 dash grapefruit bitters
1 dash Bitters #9
chilled champagne
column6: Combine the blood orange syrup, Aperol, Lillet, and bitters into a mixing glass filled with ice and stir until chilled. Strain into a chilled double rocks glass filled with ice. Top off with champagne and garnish with the blood orange twist.
column7: For the blood orange syrup: In a medium saucepan, bring 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water and the zest and juice of 2 blood oranges to a boil, stirring occasionally to dissolve the sugar. At the first crack of a boil, remove from the heat. Once cooled, pour the syrup through a strainer, discard the orange zest, and store in a glass jar. The syrup will keep in the refrigerator for a few days.
column8: Bitters: A Spirited History of a Classic Cure-all

column6: Combine the scotch, vermouth, and bitters in a mixing glass filled with ice. Stir until chilled and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with the lemon twist.

column6: Combine all the ingredients in a cocktail shaker filled with ice and shake until chilled. Double-strain into a chilled double old fashioned glass.

column5:

1 Teaspoonful simple syrup
2 Dashes Bitters #9
2 Drops Brooklyn Hemispherical Sriracha Bitters
1 Dash absinthe
column6: Coat a rocks glass with absinthe, swirl and toss out excess. Stir the remaining ingredients in a mixing glass. Strain into a rocks glass. Twist a strip of lemon peel over the glass and drop in. Top with BHB Sriracha Bitters to taste.

column5:
2 oz 100- or 101-proof rye
1/4 oz rich syrup (made with demerara or turbinado sugar instead of granulated white sugar)

column6: Combine the rye, rich syrup, and bitters in an ice-filled cocktail shaker. Shake until the ingredients are well chilled. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass and garnish with the lemon twist.

column5:
1 oz Bitters #9
1 oz freshly squeezed lime juice
1/4 oz simple syrup
1/4 oz grenadine
1/2 oz cream
1 egg white
Seltzer water
column6: Combine the bitters, lime juice, simple syrup, grenadine, cream, and egg white in a cocktail shaker. Dry shake (without ice) for approximately 10 seconds to fully combine the egg and cream. Add ice and continue to shake until chilled. Double-strain into a chilled coupe glass. Top off with seltzer.

column5:
4-6 dashes Bitters #9
Club soda or seltzer
column6: Fill a tall glass with ice. Armed with your bitters of choice, let loose with four to six vigorous shakes over the ice and then top with club soda or seltzer. Repeat as needed.
column8: Bitters book

column5:
Lemon wedge
Granulated sugar
Bitters #9
column6:
Take a lemon wedge, coat it in sugar, then douse it with some bitters. 
Bite down, and your hiccups are supposed to disappear.

Garnish: Pineapple wedge
Garnish: Pineapple leaf
